🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

The Key Strategy For Providing Effective Feedback In Remote Work Settings Is:Scheduling regular video calls check-ins for feedback.Why?Regular video calls allow for real-time, clear, and more personal communication. They help reduce misunderstandings, allow for tone and body language to be observed, and create space for dialogue. This builds trust and ensures the feedback is received constructively.The other methods can support the process:Detailed emails are useful for documenting feedback and giving time to process.Instant messaging is good for quick, informal notes but not ideal for nuanced feedback.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

The Key Strategy For Providing Effective Feedback In Remote Work Settings Is:Scheduling regular video calls check-ins for feedback.Why?Regular video calls allow for real-time, clear, and more personal communication. They help reduce misunderstandings, allow for tone and body language to be observed, and create space for dialogue. Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

The Key Strategy For Providing Effective Feedback In Remote Work Settings Is:Scheduling regular video calls check-ins for feedback.Why?Regular video calls allow for real-time, clear, and more personal communication. They help reduce misunderstandings, allow for tone and body language to be observed, and create space for dialogue. This builds trust and ensures the feedback is received constructively.The other methods can support the process:Detailed emails are useful for documenting feedback and giving time to process.Instant messaging is good for quick, informal notes but not ideal for nuanced feedback.

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.

🛡️ Where to Store Sensitive Data in Playwright When working on test automation with Playwright + TypeScript, it's crucial to keep sensitive data (like credentials, tokens, and secrets) safe and out of your source code. Here’s how to do it the right way 👇🔐 ✅ Best Practices:1️⃣ .env Files (Environment Variables)- Store secrets in a .env file.- Use packages like dotenv to load variables.- Don't forget to add .env to .gitignore!___________________________________// .envUSERNAME=testuserPASSWORD=supersecret// config.tsimport dotenv from 'dotenv';dotenv.config();export const credentials = { username: process.env.USERNAME!, password: process.env.PASSWORD!,};2️⃣ Playwright Config with use.env- You can pass secrets through use.env and access them in your tests.___________________________________// playwright.config.ts use: { env: { BASE_URL: process.env.BASE_URL, API_KEY: process.env.API_KEY, }, } 3️⃣ GitHub Actions / CI/CD Pipelines- Store secrets in GitHub Actions secrets or CI/CD vaults.- Never commit real credentials to the repo.4️⃣ Secrets Managers (Advanced)- For enterprise: Use HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, or Azure Key Vault.🚫 Avoid This: ❌ Hardcoding passwords or tokens❌ Committing .env files to your repo❌ Sharing credentials via Slack/Email🔐 Security is everyone’s responsibility — even in test automation!💬 How do you handle secrets in your automation framework? Drop your tips below 👇hashtag#playwright hashtag#typescript hashtag#automation hashtag#qa hashtag#security hashtag#devops hashtag#softwaretesting hashtag#codingbestpractices

Almost zero marketing budget? Did I hear that right? Now that I think about it, you don’t see many billboards or magazine ads for Arista.Yet it’s right up there competing with the best, if not leading. So, what are some of the key differentiators (in my opinion)? A unified software platform. It might not sound groundbreaking, but for operators and system admins, it makes a world of difference. I personally think it reflects on the engineering culture that underpins Arista’s strategy. Take SysDB, think of it as a dynamic, distributed data lake on every Arista platform. It keeps internal systems in sync, while allowing them to operate independently and respond intelligently in real time. Then there’s the fully automated 24/7 testing. Every feature, every function constantly tested. This means full regression testing for every maintenance release or bugfix, which likely explains the low volume of Arista CVEs. Arista takes a steady, robust development approach with no gimmicks, no rushed features just to tick boxes. And yet they still manage to innovate ahead of the pack. I remember back in 2014, whilst I was doing some product testing, the Arista Networks not only outperformed, the 7150 was the only product offering hardware multicast and unicast NAT. If I remember correctly, it was the only platform with a dedicated oscillator for precision timing. They were the new kid on the block but already perfectly aligned with their target audience. So, here’s my small thank you. I created a billboard poster for your advertising campaign. @AristaMarketing – feel free to use it. hashtag#Arista hashtag#AristaNetworks

**Job Posting: Live CCTV Video Streaming Developer** **Position:** Freelance/Contract Developer (Remote) **Project Duration:** [3–6 months] **Budget:** ["Negotiable"] ---### **About the Project** We’re building a mobile/web app to display live video feeds from CCTV cameras (IP-based) in real time. The goal is to integrate secure, low-latency streaming from cameras using protocols like RTSP, HLS, or WebRTC. The app will serve both Android and iOS users, with potential web integration. ---### **Responsibilities** 1. Design and implement a live video streaming system for CCTV camera feeds. 2. Integrate camera streams (RTSP, ONVIF, or HTTP/MJPEG) into the app with playback functionality. 3. Optimize latency, quality, and bandwidth usage for real-time viewing. 4. Ensure secure access (token-based authentication, VPN, HTTPS). 5. Set up a backend proxy/transcoding server (e.g., NGINX, FFmpeg) if required. 6. Collaborate with our team to troubleshoot and test across devices/networks. 7. Document the architecture and workflows. ---### **Required Skills** - **Video Streaming Expertise**:  - Protocols: RTSP, HLS, WebRTC, RTMP.  - Tools: FFmpeg, GStreamer, ExoPlayer (Android), AVPlayer (iOS), or WebRTC libraries. - **Mobile/Web Development**:  - Android (Kotlin/Java) and/or iOS (Swift) for mobile apps.  - Web: JavaScript, HLS.js, video.js, or WebRTC (React/Node.js). - **Backend/Server Skills** (if needed):  - Setting up proxy servers (NGINX RTMP, Node.js).  - Cloud services (AWS IVS, GCP) for transcoding/CDN. - **Security**: HTTPS, DRM, token authentication, firewall rules. - **Testing**: Latency optimization, codec troubleshooting (H.264/H.265). ---### **Preferred Qualifications** - Experience with CCTV/IP camera systems (e.g., ONVIF, Dahua, Hikvision). - Knowledge of IoT frameworks (e.g., AWS IoT Core). - Familiarity with analytics tools (Mux, Bitmovin). - Portfolio of similar live-streaming projects. ---### **Deliverables** 1. A working app with live CCTV feed integration. 2. Documentation for setup, maintenance, and API usage. 3. Optimized streaming pipeline with <2s latency (if possible). ---### **How to Apply** Submit your proposal with: - A brief cover letter explaining your approach to live streaming. - Examples of past projects (GitHub, demos, or case studies). - Hourly rate or project-based quote. **Contact:** [muneebumughal@gmail.com] ---### **Why Work With Us?** - Opportunity to shape a scalable video surveillance solution. - Flexible remote work with a collaborative team.
